thread.title: Queen Elizabeth's Sapphire Jubilee: 20 facts about Her Majesty as she prepares to mark 65 years on the throne
thread.title_full: Queen Elizabeth's Sapphire Jubilee: 20 facts about Her Majesty as she prepares to mark 65 years on the throne

author: Saphora Smith
title: Queen Elizabeth's Sapphire Jubilee: 20 facts about Her Majesty as she prepares to mark 65 years on the throne
text:
Queen Elizabeth II - Her Coronation Year 1/17 Pomp and ceremony 
The Queen during her lavish coronation in 1953 ITV/Rex 
The Queen was 25 years old when she ascended to the Crown ITV/Rex 3/17 National celebrations 
Pipe Major Sardar Khan of the band of the 1st Punjab Regiment outside the Criterion BBC Studios where the band recorded a broadcast for the coronation of the new Queen Getty Images 4/17 Exclusive guestlist 
Westminster Abbey was opened at 6am on the day of the coronation to allow the 8,000 guests to take their places. Those present included foreign royalty, UK Lords, heads of state, and MPs from the Queen's various legislatures ITV/Rex 5/17 Route from the Palace 
The Queen proceeded through London from Buckingham Palace, through Trafalgar Square, and towards Westminster Abbey in the 'Gold State Coach' ITV/Rex 
The Queen seen during her Coronation tour in October 1953 Daily Mail 7/17 Head of State 
The Queen inspects guard of Highland Light Infantrymen at Hampden Park, Glasgow, during her Coronation visit to Scotland in 1953 8/17 Party time 
Children with party hats and blowing trumpets at a street party in Morpeth Street, in London's East End, to celebrate the coronation Getty Images 9/17 Royal couple 
The Queen wears the Imperial State Crown as she and the Duke of Edinburgh - dressed in the uniform of Admiral of the Fleet - wave from the balcony of Buckingham Palace to the crowds 10/17 Coronation fever 
Children in the East End of London reading a poster announcing a forthcoming party to celebrate the coronation Hulton Deutsch Collection/Corbis 11/17 Long May She Reign 
As the Queen drove down the Old Kent Road she was presented with a bouquet by Mary Milledge aged 5 Daily Mail 
The Queen seen smiling from the carriage after her coronation ceremony in Westminster Abbey 13/17 Display of power 
The Queen made her Coronation Review of the greatest display of Britain's air power ever assembled, at Oldiham Airfield, Hampshire. Nearly 1.000 planes and 4,000 officers, airmen and airwomen took part, including representatives of the Commonwealth. The programme included a fly past of 639 aircraft which had taken off from 42 different airfields. Among the planes were many of the latest jets 14/17 Procession 
The royal carriage passes along Victoria Embankment on its way to Westminster Abbey AFP/Getty Images 
Undated official portrait of the Queen shortly after her coronation AFP/Getty Images 16/17 Meeting the stars 
The Queen shakes hands with Brian Donlevy, Valentina Cortesa, Peter Finch, Mona Freeman and Stewart Granger at the 'Beau Brummell' film premiere at the Empire Theatre, London, on November 15, 1954 Harry Myers/Rex 17/17 Coronation tour 
The State Banquet in Canberra, Australia, in February 1954. The Queen is wearing a mimosa gold tulle dress patterned with an Australian wattle plant motif in gold, by English designer Norman Hartnell Getty Images 
Queen Elizabeth II is set to make history as the first British monarch to celebrate her Sapphire Jubilee on Monday. 
As the nation reflects on her life and reign here are 20 facts about the Queen. 1. The Queen was born at 2.40am on April 21 1926 - the first child of the Duke and Duchess of York. 2. The infant princess was third in line to the throne - and was not expected to be Queen. 3. She was christened Elizabeth Alexandra Mary in the chapel at Buckingham Palace. Queen Elizabeth II Queen Elizabeth II 1/30 
The then the Duke and Duchess of York with their daughter Princess Elizabeth at her christening on May 1, 1926. It was not expected that Elizabeth would become Queen PA 
Princess Elizabeth waving from the carriage as she drives in London in May 1928 PA 
Princess Elizabeth arriving at Olympia for the Royal Tournament in 1930 PA 
Two-year-old Princess Margaret with her sister Princess Elizabeth in 1933 PA 5/30 
Queen Elizabeth (the Queen Mother) with her eldest daughter on the balcony of Buckingham Palace, after the coronation of King George VI in May, 1937 PA 
Princess Elizabeth after she broadcast on Children's Hour from Buckingham Palace in October 1940 PA 7/30 
Queen Elizabeth (the Queen Mother) and King George VI with Elizabeth in April 1944, shortly before her 18th birthday PA 8/30 
Elizabeth at the wheel of an Army vehicle when she served during the Second World War in the Auxiliary Territorial Service in January 1945 PA 9/30 
Princess Elizabeth and Lt Philip Mountbatten at Buckingham Palace after their wedding ceremony, November 20, 1947 PA 10/30 
Elizabeth holding her son Prince Charles after his christening ceremony in Buckingham Palace in December 1948 PA 11/30 
And with her baby daughter, Princess Anne, after her christening at Buckingham Palace in October 1950 PA 12/30 
Queen Elizabeth II, in a black mourning outfit, waving as she returns to Clarence House in London the day after she became Queen in February 1952 PA 13/30 
Queen Elizabeth wearing the St Edward Crown and carrying the Sceptre and the Rod after her coronation at Westminster Abbey, June 2 1953 PA 14/30 
Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill bowing to Queen Elizabeth as he welcomes her and the Duke of Edinburgh to 10 Downing Street for dinner in April 1955 PA 15/30 
Her Majesty holds Prince Andrew during an outing in the grounds at Balmoral, Scotland. He was the first child to be born to a reigning monarch for 103 years PA 
Queen Elizabeth wearing a leopard-skin coat at a Sandown Park race meeting in March 1962 PA 17/30 
England captain Bobby Moore receives the Jules Rimet Trophy from The Queen after England defeated West Germany on July 30, 1966 PA 18/30 
The Royal Family in the grounds of Frogmore House, Windsor, Berkshire. Left to right: Duke of Edinburgh, Princess Anne, Prince Edward, Queen Elizabeth, Prince Charles and Prince Andrew in 1968 PA 19/30 
The Queen sitting with her corgis at Virginia Water to watch competitors, including Prince Philip in the Marathon of the European Driving Championship, part of the Royal Windsor Horse Show, in May 1973 PA 20/30 
The Queen Elizabeth on a walk-about in Portsmouth during her Silver Jubilee tour of Great Britain in June 1977 PA 21/30 
Her Majesty on a walkabout during a visit to Liberia, Antigua, during her Silver Jubilee tour of the Caribbean in October 1977. The Queen has travelled around the world 42 times, visiting 117 countries according to the official count during her 90 years - and all without a passport PA 22/30 
The Queen Mother, Queen Elizabeth, Prince William, Prince Harry and the Prince and Princess of Wales after the christening ceremony of Harry in December 1984 PA 23/30 
Her Majesty takes the salute of the Household Guards regiments during the Trooping of the Colour ceremony in London in June 1985 PA 
The Queen surveys the scene at following the fire at Windsor Castle in November 1992 PA 25/30 
South Africa's President Nelson Mandela greets The Queen as she steps from the royal yacht Britannia in Cape Town at the official start of the her first visit to the country since 1947 PA 26/30 
The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh viewing the floral tributes to Diana, Princess of Wales, at Buckingham Palace following her death in 1997 PA 27/30 
Her Majesty - and Berry the corgi - with the England rugby squad after the 2003 Rugby World Cup win PA 28/30 
The Queen in the Regency Room at Buckingham Palace in London looking at some of the cards which have been sent to her for her 80th birthday in April 2006 PA 29/30 
On stage outside Buckingham Palace in London with Charles, Camilla and a host of pop stars at the Diamond Jubilee concert during celebrations to mark her 60 years as sovereign in 2012 PA 30/30 
Her Majesty attends the formal unveiling of the new logo for Crossrail, which is being named the Elizabeth line, at the construction site of the Bond Street station in central London, February 23, 2016 Richard Pohle/Reuters 
4. She is a great-great-grandchild of Queen Victoria. 
5. She was only 10 when she became heir presumptive. Her father George VI acceded to the throne after the abdication of his brother Edward VIII in 1936. 
6. She is the 40th monarch since William the Conqueror, who seized the Crown in 1066. 
7. Princess Elizabeth never went to school - she was educated at home with Princess Margaret, her younger sister. Coronation: Queen Elizabeth II wearing the St. Edward Crown and carrying the Sceptre and the Rod (PA) 
8. As a child, she was called Lilibet, and her nickname for her sister Margaret Rose was "Bud" because she was "not a real Rose yet". 
9. Shortly after her 18th birthday in 1944, she was appointed a Counsellor of State when her father was away on tour, and, for the first time, carried out some of the duties of Head of State. 
10. She undertook National Service, joining the Auxiliary Transport Service on February 24 1945, and was registered as No 230873 Second Subaltern Elizabeth Windsor. The Queen on her Golden Jubilee (Getty Images) 
11. She qualified as a driver on April 14 1945 and was promoted to Junior Commander. 
12. She could have married the Duke of Edinburgh when she was 17 - the age of his first formal request to be considered as a suitor - but her parents thought she was too young. They wed when Princess Elizabeth was 21 and have been married for nearly 70 years. 
13. At the very moment her father died in Sandringham on February 6 1952, Elizabeth, unaware of the momentous change to her life, was watching the sun rise over the jungle, having climbed to a lookout post at the top of a tree in Kenya. 
14. Elizabeth II was formally proclaimed Queen at the Accession Council on February 8 and was crowned at Westminster Abbey on June 2 1953. 
15. Her favourite tipple is gin and Dubonnet - one part gin and two parts Dubonnet. Her favourite cakes are honey and cream sponge, ginger, fruit and the chocolate biscuit cake that the Duke of Cambridge served at his wedding reception. 
16. For breakfast, the Queen has cereal with a spoonful of apricots, prunes or Macadamia nuts, or toast with light marmalade. She eats alone because the Duke of Edinburgh rises earlier and has already had his. 
17. She drinks Earl Grey tea and listens to BBC Radio 4's Today programme. The Racing Post is a favourite read. The Queen with Prince Philip the Duke of Edinburgh (PA ) 
18. The Queen has an iPod and a mobile. 
19. She sent her first tweet - signed "Elizabeth R" - from the British monarchy's official Twitter account in 2014 at the opening of a new Science Museum gallery, but it was immediately attacked by trolls sending abusive messages. 
20. Her favourite TV shows include the quiz show Pointless. She has also been a fan of Downton Abbey, Silent Witness, EastEnders, The Bill, New Tricks and Midsomer Murders. More about:
